notes.text: An update for ca-certificates is now available for Red Hat Enterprise Linux 9.
notes.title: Topic

notes.text:
The ca-certificates package contains a set of Certificate Authority (CA) certificates chosen by the Mozilla Foundation for use with the Internet Public Key Infrastructure (PKI).

Bug Fix(es) and Enhancement(s):

* Annual 2024 ca-certificates update version 2.69 from NSS 3.101.1 for Firefox 128 [rhel-9.4.z] (JIRA:RHEL-44988)

* Provide ca-certificates in directory format to resolve Application performance regression in OpenSSL [rhel-9.4.z] (JIRA:RHEL-48129)

* calling update-ca-trust on RHEL-9 should be supported with just about any argument [rhel-9.4.z] (JIRA:RHEL-54698)
notes.title: Details

document.title: Red Hat Bug Fix Advisory: ca-certificates bug fix and enhancement update

full_product_name.name: ca-certificates-0:2024.2.69_v8.0.303-91.4.el9_4.noarch as a component of Red Hat Enterprise Linux BaseOS (v. 9)
ca-certificates-0:2024.2.69_v8.0.303-91.4.el9_4.src as a component of Red Hat Enterprise Linux BaseOS (v. 9)

notes.text: A flaw was found in the python-certifi package. This issue occurs when the e-Tugra root certificate in Certifi is removed, resulting in an unspecified error that has an unknown impact and attack vector.
notes.title: Vulnerability description

notes.text: python-certifi: Removal of e-Tugra root certificate
notes.title: Vulnerability summary

notes.text:
While eTurgra certificates being marked as untrusted by Mozilla is significant from a trust and security standpoint, this is still considered a low severity issue. The certificates were removed from Mozilla's root store in July 2023, indicating a proactive response to security concerns. Additionally, Red Hat does not run its own root store program, but depends on Mozilla for ssl certificates and Microsoft for signing certificates. 
These certs are included and marked as don't trust and will not be removed until Mozilla removes them. Browsers are most at risk, which already understand and parse 'don't trust after'. If python-fi is required not to trust these certs, they should parse the 'don't trust after' attribute.
notes.title: Statement

notes.text: The CVSS score(s) listed for this vulnerability do not reflect the associated product's status, and are included for informational purposes to better understand the severity of this vulnerability.
notes.title: CVSS score applicability

remediations.details:
For details on how to apply this update, which includes the changes described in this advisory, refer to:

https://access.redhat.com/articles/11258

vulnerabilities.title: python-certifi: Removal of e-Tugra root certificate
